Description: Landscape with Bacchus at the Palace of the Dead Staphylus, based on 'Dionysiaca' by Nonnus of Panopolis (Egypt), Books XVIII, 334 f, and XIX, record of painting in the Rospigliosi-Pallavicini Collection, Rome, from the Liber Veritatis; in foreground at right group of figures, and a bull being brought for sacrifice at the funeral, beyond at left Bacchus, accompanied by other figures on the steps leading to the palace Pen and brown ink and brown wash
Curator's comments: See 1957,1214.6 for information on the Liber Veritatis. Prince Colonna commissioned a number of ambitious paintings from Claude in the latter years of his career (for discussion see 1957,1214.164), and present work probably formed a pendant to LV 175 (see 1957,1214.181). The painting that it records is in the Pallavicini Collection in Rome (inv. no. 210; canvas, 143 x 194 cm; see Roethlisberger 1986, no. 254). It is likely that the subject matter, which derives from the Dionysiaka and is an allegory of Drunkeness, was suggested to Claude by Colonna. The composition is grandiose in its conception, with a palace repeating that in LV114, and the overall attention to classical architecture comparable to other contemporary works from the 1670s and also LV157. The development of the scene can be traced through a number of highly finished drawings, all done in pen and ink and of a relatively large scale (see Roethlisberger 1968, nos. 1033–35). Two of these, one at at Besançon, the other in the the Boymans Museum (Roethlisberger 1968, no. 1035), more or less correspond, when joined together, to complete the composition and Roethlisberger argues that they were drawn separately after the two halves of the painting. Lit: M. Roethlisberger, 'Claude Lorrain, The Paintings', London 1961, LV178, pp. 418–420; M. Roethlisberger, ‘Claude Lorrain. The Drawings’, Berkeley & Los Angeles, 1968, no. 1036; M. Kitson, ‘Claude Lorrain: Liber Veritatis’, London 1978, no. 178; M. Roethlisberger, ‘Tout l’œuvre peint de Claude Lorrain’, Paris, 1986, no. 254
